In control theory, observability refers to our ability to determine the state of a dynamical system from partial observation. In cell reprogramming or differentiation experiments, we often perform the same measurements, such as RNAseq, Hi-C, or microscopy, on a group of cells throughout time or the cell cycle. Is it likely that these measurements make the system mathematically observable, and to what extent do you think we should select experimental measurements guided by observability?

In control theory, observability refers to our ability to determine the state of a dynamical system from partial observation. In cell reprogramming or differentiation experiments, we often perform the same measurements, such as RNAseq, Hi-C, or other sequencing modalities, on a group of cells throughout time or the cell cycle. If we want to take single cell measurements, however, we are no longer able to get time series data that could be used to estimate the state of a single cell over time. How can we combine the mathematical notion of observability with single cell measurements.

Epigenetic memory refers to the cellular retention of epigenetic marks, such as DNA methylation and histone modifications, which influence gene expression patterns. During cell reprogramming, these epigenetic marks can pose barriers to the complete transformation of one cell type into another by retaining memory of the original cell state. Understanding the mechanisms by which epigenetic memory affects reprogramming efficiency is crucial for advancing regenerative medicine and therapeutic interventions. How do specific epigenetic modifications impact the success of cell reprogramming techniques?

Dynamic Mode Decomposition (DMD) is a data-driven technique used to decompose complex dynamical systems into simpler, interpretable modes, often applied to analyze time-series data in fluid dynamics. In contrast, Pseudotime analysis infers the temporal progression of cellular states from single-cell RNA sequencing data, providing insights into cell differentiation and developmental processes. How might integrating DMD and Pseudotime analyses enhance our understanding of dynamic cellular processes?

Pseudotime and RNA velocity are complementary approaches used to study the dynamic progression of cellular states. While pseudotime offers a reconstructed timeline of cellular processes, RNA velocity provides insights into the immediate dynamics and directionality of gene expression changes. How can we leverage the integration of pseudotime and RNA velocity to gain deeper insights into the regulatory mechanisms driving cellular differentiation?
